column2: Description
Perform hopping, galloping, running, sliding, skipping, jumping, and landing while maintaining balance.
Perform locomotor skills in response to teacher-led creative dance.
Contrast the actions of curling and stretching the body.
Maintain momentary stillness on different bases of support.
Form wide, narrow, curled, and twisted body shapes.
Transfer weight from one foot to another, using various speeds.
Roll sideways in a narrow body shape.
Drop a ball and catch it before it bounces twice.
Catch a large ball tossed by a skilled thrower.
Toss underhand with opposite foot forward.
Dribble a ball with one hand, attempting the second contact.
Tap a ball using the inside of the foot, sending it forward.
Kick a stationary ball from a stationary position.
Volley a lightweight object (e.g., a balloon), sending it upward.
Strike a lightweight object with a short-handled implement.
Execute a single jump with self-turned rope.
Jump a long rope with teacher-assisted turning.
Description
Differentiate between movement in personal space and general space.
Travel in three different pathways.
Travel in general space with different speeds.
Description
Identify active play opportunities outside physical education class.
Actively participate in physical activities in class.
Recognize that when you move fast, your heart beats faster and you breathe more heavily.
Recognize that food provides energy for physical activity.
Recognize that proper hydration is necessary during physical activity.
Description
Follow directions in a group setting (e.g., safe behaviors, following rules, taking turns) and recognize responsible behavior while following instruction with teacher prompts and minimal reminders.
Share equipment and space with others.
Understand established procedures for class activities.
Description
Recognize that physical activity is important for good health.
Acknowledge that some physical activities are challenging and difficult.
Identify physical activities that are enjoyable.
Discuss the enjoyment of participating in activities with others.

column2: Description
Hop, gallop, jog and slide, using a mature pattern.
Demonstrate two of the five critical elements for jumping and landing in a horizontal and vertical plane, using two-foot takeoff and landing.
Combine locomotor and non-locomotor skills in a teacher-designed dance.
Demonstrate twisting, curling, bending, and stretching actions.
Maintain stillness on different bases of support with a variety of body shapes.
Transfer weight from one body part to another, using self-space in a movement environment.
Roll with either a narrow or curled body shape.
Catch a soft object from a self-toss before it bounces.
Catch various sized balls when self-tossed or tossed by a skilled thrower.
Toss underhand, demonstrating two of the five critical elements of a well-developed pattern.
Dribble continuously in personal space using preferred hand.
Tap a ball using the inside of the foot while walking in general space.
Approach a stationary ball and kick it forward, demonstrating two of the five critical elements of a well-developed pattern.
Description
Volley an object with an open palm, sending it upward.
Strike a ball with a short-handled implement, sending it upward.
Jump forward or backward consecutively, using a self-turned rope.
Jump a long rope up to five times consecutively with teacher-assisted turning.
Description
Move in personal space and general space while participating in activity or dance.
Travel demonstrating low- and high-level relationships with objects (e.g., over, under, around and through).
Differentiate between fast and slow speeds in open space.
Description
Discuss the benefits of being active and exercising.
Actively engage in physical activity during class.
Identify the heart as a muscle that grows stronger with exercise, play, and physical activity.
Differentiate between healthy and unhealthy foods.
Describe how proper hydration is important when participating in physical activity.
Description
Accept personal responsibility by using equipment and space appropriately.
Follow rules and parameters of the learning environment.
Accept personal feedback from teacher.
Work independently and with others in a variety of class environments.
Follow procedures for class activities.
Follow directions for safe participation and proper use of equipment without teacher reminders.
Description
Identify physical activity as a component of good health.
Recognize that challenges in physical activity can lead to success.
Describe positive feelings and personal reasons for enjoying physical activity.
Discuss the enjoyment of participating in activities with others.

column2: Description
Skip, demonstrating a well-developed pattern.
Run, using a well-developed pattern while differentiating between jogging and running.
Demonstrate four of the five critical elements for jumping and landing in a horizontal and vertical plane, using a variety of one-and two-foot take-offs and landings.
Perform a teacher/student-designed dance/rhythmic activity with correct response to simple rhythms.
Differentiate twisting
Balance using various levels and body shapes
Roll in different directions with a narrow or curled body shape.
Catch a self-tossed or well-thrown large ball with hands, not trapping or cradling it against the body.
Toss underhand, demonstrating three of the five critical elements of a well-developed pattern.
Throw overhand, demonstrating two of the five critical elements of a well-developed pattern.
Dribble with preferred hand in personal and general space while walking, demonstrating a well-developed pattern.
Dribble with feet in general space with control of ball and body.
Description
By means of a continuous running approach, kick a moving ball, using a well-developed kicking pattern.
Volley a lightweight object upward with consecutive hits.
While using a short-handled implement, strike an object upward with consecutive hits.
Strike a ball off a tee or cone with a long-handled implement.
Jump a self-turned rope consecutively forward and backward, using a well-developed pattern.
Jump a long rope five consecutive times with skilled student turners.
Description
Combine locomotor skills in general space.
Combine dance movement using shapes, levels and pathways with variations on time and force.
Use time and force to gradually increase and decrease movement through space.
Description
Identify physical activity outside of physical education class that contributes to fitness (e.g., before and after school, in the regular classroom, at home, with friends and family).
Participate in physical activity in response to instruction and practice.
Recognize the need for a proper balance of good nutrition and physical activity.
Describe how proper hydration is important when participating in physical activity.
Description
Accept personal responsibility for class protocol and demonstrate appropriate behavior and performance in class activities with minimal teacher prompting.
Work collaboratively in pairs and small groups.
Demonstrate safe and respectful behavior toward classmates and equipment during physical activity.
Description
Recognize the value of a healthy balance between nutrition and physical activity.
Identify physical activities that build confidence and challenge.
Identify physical activities that provide self-expression.
Discuss how working together can result in a positive outcome.
Description
Demonstrate leaping, using a mature pattern.
Establish differentiation between running and sprinting.
Develop jumping and landing in horizontal and vertical planes.
Perform teacher-selected and developmentally appropriate dance steps and movement patterns.
Move in and out of balancing, using curling, twisting and stretching actions.
Demonstrate balance and weight transfers, using movement concepts to create and perform a dance or rhythmic activity.
Catch a gently tossed ball from a partner.
Throw an underhand toss to a partner or target with reasonable accuracy.
Dribble and travel with a ball at slow to moderate jogging speed, with control of body and ball.
Perform a controlled foot dribble in general space at slow to moderate speed.
Receive a passed ball with the inside of the foot and pass to a stationary partner.
Kick a ball along the ground and in the air while running.
Description
Use a continuous running approach to kick a stationary ball for accuracy.
Perform intermediate jump rope skills using long and short ropes.
Description
Recognize open space and how using it will gain advantage.
Apply locomotor skills as they relate to a variety of activities.
Combine movement concepts (e.g., direction, force, levels, and time) with skills as directed by the teacher.
Apply simple strategies and tactics in chasing activities.
Apply simple strategies in fleeing activities.
Description
Develop a plan for participation in physical activities outside class.
Participate in activities during class without teacher prompting.
Engage in a variety of choices during recess.
Describe examples of physical activities that enhance fitness.
Recognize the importance of warm-up and cool-down.

Demonstrate, with teacher direction, the health-related fitness components of cardiovascular fitness, muscular strength, muscular endurance, and flexibility. (Body composition should not be assessed at this grade level and is not recommended.)
Generate a list of fitness-related activities in which the student participates outside of school hours.
Compare the balance of good nutrition and physical activity.
Understand the importance of hydration during physical activity.
Description
Exhibit personal responsibility in teacher-directed activities.
Work independently for extended periods of time.
Respond appropriately to suggestions given by teacher.
Work cooperatively with peers.
Recognize others' success in movement performance.
Exhibit etiquette and adherence to rules in a variety of physical activities.
Demonstrate understanding of safety, rules, and etiquette by working safely and cooperatively in physical activity settings.
Description
Discuss the relationship between physical activity and good health.
Reflect on the personal selection of particular physical activities over other options.
Discuss the challenge that comes from learning a new physical activity.
Describe the positive social interactions that result from participation in physical activity.

column2: Description
Use spring-and-step takeoffs while jumping and landing.
Run for distance, using pacing and a well-developed pattern.
Move into and out of balances with curling, twisting, and stretching actions.
Combine locomotor skills and movement concepts (e.g., levels, shapes, extensions, pathways, force, time, and flow) to create and perform a dance or rhythmic activity with a partner.
Combine locomotor movement patterns and dance steps to create and perform an original dance.
Use various motor skills in a variety of small group practice tasks.
Catch and throw a ball above the head, at chest/waist level, and below the waist, using a well-developed pattern in a non-dynamic environment.
Throw underhand to a partner or at a target with accuracy and increased distance.
Dribble with the hand in personal space with both the preferred and non-preferred hand, using a well-developed pattern.
Dribble in general space, with control of ball and body while increasing and decreasing speed.
Throw overhand, using a well-developed pattern with accuracy.
Description
Throw overhand to a partner, or at a target at a reasonable distance.
Volley with a two-hand overhead pattern, sending a ball upward with consecutive hits.
Dribble with feet in general space, maintaining control of ball and body while increasing and decreasing speed.
Receive a ball with the insides of the foot and pass to a moving partner in a non-dynamic environment.
Receive a ball with the outside and inside of the foot and return the pass to a stationary partner.
Combine traveling with the manipulative skills of dribbling, throwing, catching and striking in teacher- and/or student-designed small group activities (3-5 students).
Create and perform a jump rope routine with either a short or long rope.
Description
Apply the concept of open spaces to combination skills (e.g., getting open for a pass, dribbling to create space).
Apply the movement concepts of speed, endurance, and pacing for running.
Combine movement concepts with skills in small group (3-5 students) activities and/or dance.
Apply the concepts of direction and force when striking an object with a short-handled implement, sending it toward a designated target.
Apply simple offensive strategies and tactics in chasing and fleeing activities.
Apply simple defensive strategies/tactics in chasing and fleeing activities.
Recognize the types of kicks needed for different game and sport situations.
Description
Analyze opportunities for participating in physical activity outside physical education class.
Actively engage in the activities of physical education class, both teacher-directed and independent.
Identify the components of health-related fitness (e.g., cardiovascular fitness, muscular strength, muscular endurance, and flexibility).
Demonstrate prescribed warm-up and cool-down relative to level of exercise.
Description
Exhibit responsible behavior in independent group situations.
Reflect on personal social behavior in physical activity.
Listen respectfully to corrective feedback from others (e.g., peers, adults).
Praise the movement performance of others both more and less skilled.
Accept students of all skill levels into the physical activity.
Exhibit etiquette and adherence to rules in a variety of physical activities.
Work safely with peers and equipment in physical activity settings.
Description
Examine the health benefits of participating in physical activity.
Rate the enjoyment of participating in challenging and mastered physical activities.
Critique the level of enjoyment after participating in various physical activities.
Describe/compare the positive social interactions when engaged in partner, small group and large group physical activities.
Description
Demonstrate a well-developed pattern of locomotor skills in small group practice tasks and dance.
Demonstrate a combination of locomotor and manipulative skills in a variety of small group activities.
Create a combination of moving and shooting skills to a scoring target.
Run various distances, demonstrating an understanding of pace for highest performance.
Use locomotor skills in cultural as well as creative dances with correct rhythm and pattern.
Participate in a small group activity or dance using curling, twisting, and stretching actions.
Catch a ball above the head, chest, at waist level, and along the ground using a well-developed pattern, with or without a partner.
Throw and catch a ball while both partners are moving.
Catch and throw a ball with accuracy in small group activities.
Combine foot dribbling with other skills in practice using one-on-one tasks.
Use feet to dribble and pass while moving with a partner.
Dribble with one hand or foot with accuracy in a small group activity.
Volley a ball using a two-hand overhead pattern, sending it upward to a target.
Description
Combine manipulative skills while moving toward a target to execute a score.
Create a jump rope routine with a partner, using either a short or long rope.
Description
Combine spatial concepts with locomotor and non-locomotor movement in small group and dance activities.
Use movement strategies in small game situations.
Apply direction and force when striking an object with a long-handled implement, sending it toward a designated target.
Use basic offensive and defensive strategies and tactics in small group games.
Distinguish the type of throw, volley or striking action needed for different activities and sporting games.
Description
Chart and analyze physical activity outside physical education class, identifying the fitness benefits.
Engage in a wide variety of physical activities.
Identify the components of skill-related fitness (e.g., agility, balance, coordination, power, reaction time, speed).
Recognize the need for warm-up and cool-down relative to various physical activities.
Chart results of fitness assessment (pre and post). Compare the results as they relate to good health.
Design a fitness plan to address ways to use physical activity to enhance fitness.
Description
Analyze the impact of food choices and hydration relative to physical activity, sports, and personal health.
Select physical activities to reduce stress outside of class.
Demonstrate interpersonal behavior with peers and teachers during physical activity.
Exhibit respect for self with appropriate behavior while engaging in physical activity.
Respectfully give feedback to peers.
Accept, recognize, and actively involve others with both higher and lower skill abilities into physical activities and group projects.
Apply safety principles while engaged in age-appropriate physical activities.
Compare various physical activities and the benefits derived from participation.
Express (in a written essay, visual art, or creative dance) the enjoyment and/or challenge of participating in a favorite physical activity.
Analyze different physical activities for enjoyment and challenge; identify reasons for positive or negative responses.
Describe the social benefits gained from participating in physical activity.
Description
Create an open space by using locomotor movement and change of speed and direction during activity.
Demonstrate competency in locomotor skills as applied to small group games (i.e., 3-5 players), such as basketball, flag football, and speedball.
Combine movement with manipulative skills to reach a target and score a goal (e.g., soccer, hockey, basketball).
Demonstrate correct rhythm and patterns for a dance form (e.g., folk, social, creative, line or world dance).
Perform a rhythmic dance using drumming, and incorporate complete movement using ropes, balls, or Lummi sticks.
Use locomotor and non-locomotor skills to teach a group dance or rhythmic activity.
Catch a variety of objects from different trajectories, using varying practice tasks.
Execute consistently (i.e., 70% of the time) a well-developed underhand pattern for target games such as bowling, bocci, or horseshoes.
Dribble with the dominant hand, using a change of speed and direction in a variety of practice tasks.
Complete a variety of practice tasks; dribble with control, changing speed and direction.
Pass and receive with the feet, using a well-developed pattern in a small group activity.
Description
Demonstrate a complete skill by dribbling and shooting on goal with power in a game setting.
Demonstrate a well-developed form of the overhead volley through implementation in a game setting.
Create a jump rope routine with repeated patterns and combinations of movement.
Description
Demonstrate individual strategies in a small group setting in both defensive and offensive situations to create or deny open space.
Apply speed, direction, and force using a long-handled implement, sending it toward a specific target area while in motion.
Execute an offensive tactic, such as pivots, fakes, or change of direction away from the ball, to create open space.
Reduce open space on defense, by making the body larger and reducing the passing angles.
Description
Record daily activity and identify benefits gained. Describe how being physically active leads to a healthy body.
Participate in self-selected physical activity outside of physical education class.
Differentiate between skill-related and health-related fitness.
Explain the role of warm-up and cool-down before and after physical activity.
Design and implement a program of remediation for any area of weakness based on results of health-related fitness assessment.
Select food within each of the basic food groups, and select appropriate servings and portions for age and physical activity level.
Description
Identify positive and negative results from stress and appropriate ways of dealing with each.
Exhibit personal responsibility by using appropriate etiquette, demonstrate respect for facilities, and exhibit safe behaviors.
Identify and use appropriate strategies to self-reinforce positive fitness behaviors, such as positive self-talk.
Demonstrate understanding that there are differences among classmates in physical development, maturation and varying skill levels by providing encouragement and positive feedback to peers.
Demonstrate understanding of rules and etiquette for physical activities, games, and dance.
Use physical activity and fitness equipment appropriately and safely, with minimal teacher guidance.
Describe how being physically active leads to a healthy body.
Identify why physical activity participation reduces stress and promotes positive social interaction.
Understand that personal challenges can be positive, and reaction can build personal satisfaction through acceptance of feedback, extending effort, and not being afraid to ask for help.
Describe how participation in a physical activity creates enjoyment.
Demonstrate respect for self and others in activities and games by following the rules, encouraging others, and playing in the spirit of the game or activity.

column2: Description
Throw with a mature pattern for distance or power (e.g., throw from outfield to home, or from second base to first base).
Catch with a mature pattern from a variety of trajectories using different equipment (e.g. softball, basketball, Frisbee, team handball).
Perform correct rhythm and pattern for dance (e.g., folk, social, creative, line, or original).
Create open space using pivots, fakes, and jab steps during a practice.
Dribble with dominant hand, changing speed and direction in practice.
Shoot using power in a dynamic setting to score a goal (e.g., basketball or soccer).
Serve underhand with control over a net (e.g., volleyball, badminton, pickleball).
Demonstrate the ready position for defense in a small game setting.
Demonstrate the mature forehand and backhand stoke using a short-handled implement in net games (e.g., paddle ball, pickleball, or short-handled tennis).
Demonstrate correct weight transfer for a striking pattern.
Perform a two-hand volley with control to a target in a variety of practice settings.
Execute a mature underhand pattern for target games succeeding 70% of the time (e.g., bowling, bocci, horseshoes).
Description
Strike a stationary object with an implement (e.g., croquet, shuffleboard, golf).
Strike a pitched ball with force in a practice setting.
Create open space by using locomotor skills (e.g., walking, running, jumping and landing) in combination with movement skills (e.g., varying pathways, changing speed, direction or pace).
Reduce open space on defense by making the body larger or reducing passing angles.
Reduce open space by denying the catch or allowing the catch, but not the return pass.
Demonstrate transition from offense to defense, or defense to offense through quick recovery.
Recognize open space and attempt to strike an object into that space.
Identify the correct defensive play based on the situation (e.g., number of outs in softball).
Change force application during a dance or gymnastic activity.
Describe how being physically active leads to a healthy body.
Participate in self-selected physical activity outside of physical education class.
Participate in a variety of aerobic fitness activities (e.g., cardio kick, step aerobics, aerobic dance).
Participate in a fitness program using technology outside of physical education class.
Description
Research a variety of recreational activities or sports.
Identify the components of skill-related fitness.
Record levels of activity, including levels of intensity, for at least 60 minutes per day.
Apply and demonstrate correct techniques and methods of stretching.
Differentiate between aerobic and anaerobic capacity, and between muscle strength and endurance.
Describe the importance of warm-up and cool-down for activity.
Define resting heart rate (RHR) and how aerobic fitness relates to low or high fitness levels.
Identify major muscles used in selected physical activities.
Design and implement a personal program to remediate any area of weakness based on health-related fitness test.
Maintain a physical activity log for at least two weeks that reflects activity levels and results.
Identify foods and appropriate servings for personal needs and a healthy body.
List positive and negative results of stress and ways to deal with each.
Description
Show personal responsibility by using appropriate etiquette, respecting facilities and exhibiting safe behavior.
Accept differences among peers with regard to physical development, maturity, and varying skill levels by giving positive feedback and encourages classmates.
Cooperate with small group during game play or team-building activities.
Identify rules for activities, games, and dance activities.
Description
Use activity equipment appropriately and safely under teacher guidance.
Describe how being physically active leads to a healthy body.
Identify components of physical activities that reduce stress and provide social interaction.
Recognize challenges and respond in a positive way (e.g., ask for help, extend effort, or modify the task).
Describe how skill competency increases enjoyment in activity settings.
Identify how self-expression and physical activity are related.
Participate in games or activities in the spirit of the game.
Description
Demonstrate the correct technique for a variety of locomotor skills (e.g., sliding, galloping and hopping in small group activities).
Demonstrate the correct technique for non-locomotor skills (e.g., stretching, bending, twisting during small group activity or dance).
Perform manipulative skills while working with a partner (e.g., dribbling a basketball, kicking a soccer ball, passing a volleyball overhead).
Identify which aspects of weight transfer are common in a variety of skills (e.g., throwing, batting, kicking).
Identify which aspects of opposition and follow-through are common in a variety of skills (e.g., throwing, tennis serve, soccer kick, volleyball spike, basketball lay-up).
Identify aspects of body and target alignment that are common for a variety of skills.
Perform a variety of dances, such as square, fold, aerobic, modern, ball-room and line.
Perform a variety of tumbling and dance activities that combine traveling, rolling, balancing, and weight transfer into smooth flowing sequences.
Description
Link skills together (e.g., dribble and pass a basketball, receive and drib-ble a soccer ball, kick, receive a soccer pass, and kick a goal).

Perform skills in an increasingly complex environment (e.g., from drib-bling to dribbling on the run, from throwing football from a stationary to a moving target, hitting a stationary hockey puck to hitting a moving puck).
Understand how moving to open space and gaining position can bene-fit performance in a variety of game situations.
Move to an open space to receive a pass while playing small group activities.
Cover a specific area of the court or field while playing small group activities.
Dribble
column4: and receive a ball while stationary.

column2: Establish a ready position for skill performance (e.g., receiving a tennis serve or ground ball in softball).
Strike or throw a ball to a specific target.
Description
Assess own fitness level and create personal fitness goals (e.g., assessment of strength, muscular endurance, cardiovascular endurance, flexibility).
Create personal goals based on fitness assessment results.
Monitor progress toward personal fitness goals using a checklist or journal.
Explain the components and principles of health-related fitness.
Identify activities that participation in can improve each component in health-related fitness (e.g., strength, muscular endurance, cardiovascular endurance, flexibility).
Explain the importance of warm-up and cool-down during exercise.
Description
Explore a variety of new physical activities during physical education class that encourage personal interest outside of class.
Investigate the concept of energy balance as it relates to nutrition and exercise.
Identify poor food choices and healthy food alternatives.
Demonstrate proper posture while standing, sitting, and lifting.
Identify opposing muscle groups and how they relate to training.
Use technology to monitor and improve physical activity and wellness.
Evaluate technological resources as related to development of fitness and exercise programs. (e.g., heart rate monitors, pedometers, computer software and Internet resources).
Description
Demonstrate an understanding of different skill levels among peers in physical activity settings.
Recognize the role of games, sports, and dance in getting to know and respect others of various cultural backgrounds.
Consider various strategies for resolving personal conflict with sensitivity to the rights and feeling of others.
Understand and apply inclusive rules to include less skilled players. Identify exclusionary behavior that purposely omits students from being included.
Description
Identify the activities that bring personal enjoyment.
Celebrate the successes and achievements of self and others.
Description
Identify the feelings resulting from meeting challenges.
Explain how physical activity can provide enjoyable social interaction.
Explain the social benefits that result from team and dual sport participation
Differentiate between appropriate and inappropriate risks.
Create a plan to include activity beyond school years.
Description
Demonstrate competency in a variety of movement forms and proficiency in some movement forms.
Apply manipulative skills in a variety of individual, dual, and team sport-specific activities.
Demonstrate weight transfer that is common for a variety of skills (e.g., throwing, batting, and kicking).
Perform manipulative skills while working individually (e.g., throw, kick, and strike a variety of objects, demonstrating both accuracy and force).
Combine manipulative skills while working with a partner or within a small group (e.g., hit a ball and run to base, dribble and shoot a basketball while being guarded, catch and throw a Frisbee).
Demonstrate body and target alignment that are common for a variety of skills (e.g., receiving a serve, catching a ball, catching a Frisbee).
Demonstrate how opposition and follow-through are common for a variety of skills (e.g., throwing, tennis serve, soccer kick, volleyball spike, basketball lay-up).
Use correct technique in a variety of lead-up games.
Create and perform a variety of dances such as square, folk, aerobic, modern, ballroom, line, and cultural.
Create and perform a variety of activities that combine traveling, rolling, balancing, and weight transfer into a smooth-flowing sequence.
Description
Demonstrate through participation, ways to link and transfer basic manipulative skills and concepts to specialized sports' skills.
Identify and demonstrate similarities and differences between motor skills (e.g., the badminton smash and volleyball spike, drop kick in soccer and punt in football).
List goals and monitor changes in the development of movement skills to improve performance.
In a game situation, move to open spaces to receive a pass while playing traditional or non-traditional sports or activities.
Cover a specific area of the court or field while playing traditional or non-traditional sports or activities.
Establish a ready position in preparation for skill performance (e.g., receiving a volleyball serve or ground ball in softball or lacrosse).
Strike or throw a ball to a specific target.
Throw and catch a Frisbee while running.
Description

Assess personal level of fitness and maintain a basic exercise plan, including all components of health related fitness (e.g., assessment of strength, muscular endurance, cardiovascular endurance, flexibility).
Design and implement a personal exercise plan based on fitness assessment results.
Monitor progress by utilizing advanced techniques, including computer programs.
Change activities or alter game rules to enhance fitness benefits (e.g., eliminate time-outs, play soccer instead of volleyball to meet cardiovascular goals).
Description
Explore a variety of nontraditional physical activities for personal interest inside and outside of class (e.g., orienteering, field hockey, hiking).
Define the components of health related fitness, describe application of the components, and create activities that are appropriate for improvement for each component.
Describe the relationship between physical activity and food intake.
Discuss the concept of energy balance.
Complete a two-day diet and activity log. Using log information, identify poor food choices and healthy alternatives.
Describe a diet for optimal physical performance.
Demonstrate proper posture while performing selected activities and exercises.
Identify exercises that contribute to trunk stabilization and the importance of equal strength in opposing muscle groups.
Examine, monitor, and improve execution of motor skills using technological resources.

Using technology, provide skill feedback and analysis of movement (e.g., comparing the speed of approach and body position in the long jump, rotation of the trunk, and angle of release of the shot put).
Description
Demonstrate the ability to make responsible choices in activity settings.
Demonstrate while participating compliance with activity rules and procedures.
Practice safe behaviors relative to others.
Strive to keep the importance of winning and losing in perspective.
Accept and consider constructive criticism or feedback for teacher and peers.
Demonstrate the ability to work and support others with both teammates and opponents.
Description
Develop a democratic plan to solve problems or make decisions in physical activity.
Seek out, participate with, and show respect for persons of like and different genders, abilities, skills, and cultures.
Value the role of games, sports, and dance in getting to know and respect others of various cultural backgrounds.
Recognize that physical activity provides opportunities for enjoyment.
Celebrate the successes and achievements of self and others.
Recognize that physical activity provides opportunities for challenge.
Develop personal strategies for overcoming fear of participating in new activities.
Recognize that physical activity provides opportunities for self-expression.
Use creative means to express the aesthetic and creative aspects of performance (e.g., collages, poems, posters, slide show, video, song, and dance).
Participate in physical activities that provide enjoyable social interaction.
Describe the social benefits that result from team and individual sport participation.
Demonstrate group problem solving abilities.
Description

Participate in and/or refine activity-specific movement skills in five or more lifetime activities (e.g., outdoor pursuits, individual performance activities, non-traditional, aquatics, net/wall games, or target games) and/or in dance forms (e.g., cultural and social occasions, ballet, modern, hip-hop, tap).
Demonstrate individual competency through testing and participation in five or more lifetime activities and/or in dance forms used in cultural and social occasions.
Participate in aerobic and anaerobic activities that will promote health-related fitness.
Demonstrate individual competency in one or more aerobic and anaerobic skills that promote health-related fitness.
Employ offensive maneuvers to receive a pass in a game setting.
Accomplish efficient defensive understanding in a game situation by denying passing zones, or deflecting ball.

Definition
Correct positioning of parts of the body for ease, efficiency, and safety of movement.
Movement that stays around a central axis and does not travel through space.
The dynamic principle or subtle adjustment the dancer uses while standing or during movement.
Plié, relevé, tendu, dégagé, battements, passé, rond de jambe, pirouette, chassé, chaîné, coupé, pointe, flex
The act of designing a dance sequence that is set and repeatable.
The aesthetic arrangement and technical structure of a piece of choreography
Dance from different geographical areas based in the culture and traditions of the people (e.g., African, Chinese, Russian, Polynesian, Latin, Indian, folk dance).
Standards of behavior and respectful interaction in dance spaces such as rehearsal, audience roles, professional or production experiences, and performance
Different styles of developed and recognizable forms of dance (e.g., ballet, jazz, modern, contemporary, urban, social, ballroom, tap, clog, musical theater, cultural forms)
locomotor, axial, isolation, segmentation
levels, pathways, direction changes, range, positive negative space, relationship, body-shape
metric, non metric,natural rhythm, tempo, rhythm, accelerate, decelerate
energy qualities (vibratory, swing, sway, percussive, sustain, suspend, collapse, explosive) - Force- bound, free, heavy, light, strong, weak

Ways of perceiving, interacting with, and understanding dance; often based on the choreographers' intent and/or the audience's perspective. Dance can fit and function within any framework, or multiple frameworks at once. The definitions below give a general outline of certain approaches, but dance consumers and creators should be aware that these frameworks often overlap, fuse, and layer over each other.
Dance performed to primarily express ideas; dance for arts' sake; often portrays and interprets aspects of life in order to challenge or confirm the values of the audience.

Dance performed in competitions, for the purpose of winning against other competitors; often created and performed to fulfill standardized, points-based scoring rubrics (e.g. drill team, dance sport, ballroom).
Definition
The use of dance and/or dance principles to study, explore, and better understand aspects of life and humanity (e.g., body storming, scientific studies).
Dance performed for the purpose of entertaining audiences (e.g., television, movies, commercial forms, musical theater).
Dance used for community building and development of social connections (e.g., school performances, dance therapy, social dance).
Spontaneous movement to explore a prompt or challenge that often leads to movement used in choreography.
Moving individual parts of the body while the rest of the body stays still or moves in a different direction.
The study of human movement, physical activity, and kinetic chains as they relate to sport, dance, and exercise.
Movement that travels through space (e.g., walk, run, leap, skip, gallop)
Perception or awareness of the position and movement of the body
Body movement by division into separate parts or sections

Technique is the basis of all fundamentals of dance, from holding your body correctly while performing, to executing steps and skills properly and efficiently in movement. Strong technique extends across all genres of dance.

column2: Definition
The point about which the body's weight is evenly distributed in any position.
Exercise program similar to an obstacle course, in which a person goes from station to station, doing a different exercise at each station.
Activity at the end of a workout that brings the mind and body back to a relaxed state. It helps in eliminating by-products of exercise, such as lactic acid, and helps to reduce injury.
The ability to control and put together movements by different parts of the body to perform movement skills smoothly and accurately.
Food group consisting of all fluid milk products and many foods made from milk.
Teaching and learning that meet the needs of students as their abilities change with age, experience, and maturity.
Amount of time spent in a physical activity.
The quality of performance of a skill with minimal use of time and energy.
Basic part of movement.
Stamina; the ability to exercise for long periods of time to develop cardiovascular and muscular endurance.
Participating with integrity and respect for teammates, opponents, officials, and rules.
Energy-rich substances such as butter and oils.
Movement coordination utilizing small groups of muscles in delicate, precise movements (e.g., writing, tying shoelaces, wrist action in table tennis).

A fitness principle that involves frequency, intensity, time, and type of exercise. 1. Frequency: How often a person performs the target health-related physical activity. 2. Intensity: How hard a person exercises during a physical activity period.
Definition
How long an activity should be performed (duration).
What kind of activity a person chooses to perform in each area of health-related fitness.
The range of motion available at a given joint of the body; one of five components of health-related fitness.
Method of performing movement activities according to recognized standards of technique.
The number of exercise sessions during a specific time.

Basic movement patterns usually involving large muscle groups, enabling such skills as walking, running, hopping, skipping, jumping, leaping, and galloping, as well as throwing, passing, kicking, dribbling, and catching.
Area of space outside the normal reach of the body.
Any food made from wheat, rice, oats, cornmeal, barley, or another cereal grain product.
Skills involving large muscle groups (e.g., throwing a baseball, kicking a soccer ball, serving a volleyball).
Improving overall health and well-being through attention to cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength and endurance, flexibility, body composition, and proper nutrition.
The number of heartbeats in a minute.
Energy expended to perform activities at various levels of proficiency.
Games that develop basic skills and competencies related to sports and activities.
Activities that a person carries out in the course of daily life and that can contribute to sizeable energy expenditures.
Skills used to move the body from one place to another. Basic locomotor steps include walking, running, hopping, jumping, leaping, skipping, sliding, and galloping.
Small sticks (wands) used to work on rhythmic tapping, flipping, and catching.
Skills developed to assist a person in throwing, catching, or redirecting the flight of a ball or other object.
Movement that occurs in conjunction with an object (i.e., dribbling a basketball, volleying a volleyball)
Highest heart rate attainable when exercising in an all-out effort to the point of exhaustion (general formula: 220-age).

Sustained, repetitive, large-muscle activities (e.g., walking, running, cycling) done at less than 60 percent of maximum heart range for age. The maximum heart rate is 220 beats per minute minus the participant's age.
The learned ability to perform a physical activity efficiently, successfully, and consistently.
An organized series of related movements.
The ability of the muscles to perform without fatigue for an extended period of time. One of the five components of health-related fitness.
The amount of force that is produced by muscles contracting, as measured by one maximum attempt in an activity. One of the five components of health-related fitness.
A tool to find your healthy eating style and build it throughout your lifetime.
Stationary skill that does not produce displacement of the body (e.g., bending, holding, lifting, pulling, pushing, stretching, twisting, turning).
Skill not involving throwing, striking, or catching and receiving an object.
A basic component of food that nourishes the body.
Fat that is liquid at room temperature.

When throwing a ball, stepping with the foot opposite the throwing
hand.

Patterns of travel while performing movement activities (e.g., straight,
curved, zigzag).

Space immediately surrounding a child that is carried with the child as
he/she moves through general space during an activity.

Any fitness, sports, or recreational activity involving movement of the
body that is produced through muscle contraction and increases ener-
gy expenditure. These activities can require light, moderate, or vigorous
effort and can lead to improved health if they are practiced regularly.
Children need 60 minutes or more a day of moderate to vigorous physi-
cal activity (MVPA) a day.
1. Light activity: not sitting still or lying down.
2. Moderate activity: activity that increases your heart and breathing
rate and makes you sweat. For example, you can talk but cannot sing.
3. Vigorous activity: activity in which you are breathing rapidly and un-
able to speak in long sentences, only short phrases. Your heart rate is
substantially increased and you are noticeably sweating.

A planned, sequential curriculum of strategies to help students devel-
op and maintain a healthy lifestyle. It includes cognitive and physical
aspects of sport and activity, goal setting, proper nutrition, and formal
assessment.

The ability to carry out daily tasks with vigor and alertness, without un-
due fatigue, and with ample energy to enjoy leisure-time pursuits and
respond to emergencies.
The mastery of a specific skill.

Starting an exercise slowly and gradually increasing the intensity and
duration.

Substances that build and repair the body, especially muscle tissue.
Protein-rich foods include meat, eggs, cheese, nuts, soybeans, etc.

The rhythmic beat of the blood pumped by the heart through the arter-
ies that can be felt on the wrist and at the side of the neck.

The time it takes to move after hearing, seeing, feeling, or touching; the
time from stimulus to reaction.
The number of times an exercise is repeated.
Willingness to show consideration or appreciation for one another (e.g., listening to others, not using put-downs).
The heart rate at rest, generally 60-80 beats/minute.
Use of hands, feet, drums, recorded and/or segments of music of various tempos.
A set of scoring guidelines for assessing student skills and knowledge.
Space that the body or its parts can reach without leaving a starting position.
Orderly movement from one pattern to the next.
Skills that will enhance one's performance in athletic or sports events. There are six components of skill-related fitness: agility, balance, coordination, speed, power, and reaction time.
Perception of the body as it moves in relation to the physical environment and fellow participants; includes general and self-space, directions, pathways, levels, and extensions.
The distance covered in a certain period of time.
The ability of muscle or muscle groups to exert force. One of the five components of health-related fitness.
Maintaining an exercise rate between 60 and 80 percent of the maximum heart rate.
Any electronic device used during physical activity, such as heart-rate monitors, pulse monitors, pedometers, calorie counters, stopwatches, video cameras, DVDs, and apps.
A rhythmic activity that involves various rhythmic movements inside and outside of two eight-foot poles.

Sustained and repetitive large-muscle movements (e.g., running, swimming, playing soccer) done at 60 percent or more of the maximum heart rate for one's age. (The maximum heart rate is 220 beats per minute minus the participant's age.) Vigorous activity is characterized by sweating and breathing hard.
Definition
Activity that involves a gradual increase in the heart and breathing rates, and a slight rise in body temperature, and that prepares the mind and body for activity.
Includes five parts or dimensions: physical/body, emotional, social, intellectual, and environmental.
